context: [3] The urea cycle is an essential pathway to eliminate ammonia through its conversion to urea (Fig. 1). [4] Because the enzymes involved in this pathway are highly expressed in the liver, this organ has an essential role in ammonia elimination. [5] Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC), the second enzyme in the urea cycle, catalyzes the condensation of ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to form citrulline . [6] OTC deficiency, the most common and severe inborn error in the urea cycle, causes hyperammonemia, mental retardation, and finally death because of hyperammonemic coma . [1] Schematic representation of ureagenesis pathway. [2] Amino acids were converted into ammonia (NH3) via transamination by aminotransferases such as alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) followed by oxidative deamination by glutamate dehydrogenase and glutaminase. [3] Ammonia is then converted into urea via the urea cycle (CPS I, OTC, ASS, ASL, and arginase I).
